journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Intelligent Material Systems and Structures

title-group.article-title: Design and testing of an enhanced shape memory actuator elastically compensated by a bistable rocker arm

contrib-group.aff: Department of Engineering Sciences and Methods, University of Modena and Reggio Emilia, Reggio Emilia, Italy

author-notes.corresp: Eugenio Dragoni, Department of Engineering Sciences and Methods, University of Modena and Reggio Emilia, via Amendola 2, 42122 Reggio Emilia, Italy. Email: eugenio.dragoni@unimore.it

article-meta.issue-title: Special issue on: ASME 2011 Conference on Smart Materials, Adaptive Structures and Intelligent Systems (SMASIS), Symposium on Modeling, Simulation and Control: Part 1

abstract.p: This article presents the design, the prototype construction, and the experimental testing of a shape memory actuator implementing the concept of elastic compensation put forward in a previous publication by the authors. A two-shape memory alloy actuator, compensated by a spring-assisted bistable rocker arm, is designed theoretically to provide nearly constant output forces and then it is built and characterized experimentally under laboratory conditions. The test results closely agree with the theoretical predictions and show that for given output force, the compensated actuator produces net strokes from 2.5 to 22 times greater than a twin uncompensated actuator. The stroke improvement increases dramatically with the generated output force. Weaknesses of the compensated design are the heavier average stress sustained by the shape memory alloy springs, which could impair the fatigue life, and a higher response time.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Although shape memory alloy (SMA) actuators can generate considerable forces, they typically exhibit small displacements (Nespoli et al., 2010; Warith et al., 1998). The net stroke is chiefly limited by the maximum strain that the shape memory material can withstand for the desired service life (Spinella and Dragoni, 2009a). A further loss of stroke comes from the contrasting action of the backup element (weight, classical spring, and second SMA spring), which prevents the active material from fully recovering the memorized shape (Waram, 1993).

The usual force–displacement curve of shape memory actuators is a straight line with the peak force achieved at one end of the stroke and zero force at the other end (Spinella et al., 2009b). This characteristic does not fit well with the fact that the external load is often constant over the stroke. As a rule (refer section “Theory”), for given output force, the stroke of the actuator increases as the stiffness of the backup element decreases. Thus, a constant backup force (dead weight) is more efficient than a conventional spring. This trend suggests that a backup system with negative slope (compensation system) would provide even higher displacements than traditional solutions.

In the field of dielectric polymer actuators, the concept of elastic compensation is well known (Berselli et al., 2009; Chouinard and Plante, 2011; Plante and Dubowsky, 2008) and routinely exploited to improve the performance of the devices. Its application to the category of SMA actuators can be traced back to the study of Ishii and Ting (2004) and has remained virtually unexplored since then. In a recent publication (Scirè Mammano and Dragoni, 2011a), the authors presented a general theory, showing the advantages of the compensation concept for SMA actuators. The theory gives the elastic characteristics of the compensation system starting from the prescribed values of output force and stroke. That article also suggests the architecture of two specific bistable mechanisms as practical embodiments of the compensated design. Other architectures for compensation mechanisms can be retrieved from the abundant literature on bistable linkages and constant force generators (Nathan, 1985; Rahman et al., 1995).

Building on that theory, this article focuses on the experimental characterization of a compensated SMA actuator powered by two antagonistic SMA springs. The compensation mechanism is a bistable rocker arm equipped with an elastic spring, which takes power from the SMA springs in positions where the internal force is high, and then returns this power in positions where the force is low. A compensated prototype is designed in detail, manufactured, and tested to validate the theory and compare the performance with an uncompensated actuator of otherwise identical architecture.

In agreement with the theoretical model, the tests show that the compensated actuator has an overall stroke of 2.5 times higher than its uncompensated counterpart under no external force (positioning application). It is also seen that the compensated actuator retains the full stroke up to the maximum achievable force, while in the uncompensated actuator, the stroke steadily decreases as the output force increases. A weak point of the compensated design is the slower response time to begin the displacement upon activation and a generally higher working stress in the SMA springs.

Due to their intrinsic bistable behavior, primary applications of elastic compensated actuators are expected in the area of positioning devices and binary robotics. In the latter area, the robot can achieve a large number of indexed configurations by suitable combination of the binary states of a relatively small number of actuators (Plante and Dubowsky, 2008).

sec.title: Principle of elastic compensation
sec.p: The force–deflection diagram in Figure 1 shows the characteristic lines of an SMA actuator in the austenitic state (hot SMA) and martensitic state (cold SMA). When the SMA element is backed up by an elastic spring with the linear characteristic shown with solid circles, the net stroke under no external force is Sspring. Starting from the same maximum deflection and force of the cold SMA, the stroke increases to Sweight when the active element is backed up by a constant force (crossed horizontal line). The improvement depends upon the reduced stiffness (lower contrasting forces) of the backup element that allows the SMA to recover a greater share of deformation in passing from the cold state to the hot state.

caption.p: Force–deflection curves of a single-SMA actuator backed up by a conventional spring, a constant force, and an elastic compensation system.

sec.p: By learning from this positive trend, it is easily seen that an even greater stroke (Scomp) is achieved if the backup element displays a negative slope (hollow circles) so that the contrast force would decrease with increasing deflection. Energetically, the compensation system accumulates energy from the SMA element in the positions where the force of the hot SMA is high (right-hand side in Figure 1) and releases that energy to the actuator in the positions where the SMA force is low (left-hand side in Figure 1).

As will be shown later, a backup element with negative slope as in Figure 1 can be achieved by exploiting one of the many spring-assisted monostable or bistable mechanisms as described in the technical literature (Berselli et al., 2009; Ishii and Ting, 2004; Nathan, 1985; Rahman et al., 1995).

The use of an elastic compensation system requires the introduction of hard stops to prevent the SMA elements from overstraining. In the case of a single-SMA actuator (see Figure 1), a single hard stop is needed on the left-hand side, and the behavior upon power shutoff becomes monostable. In the case of a double-SMA actuator, two hard stops are required and the behavior is bistable when no power is supplied.

Although the advantages of the compensation system in terms of force and stroke apply to both single-SMA and two-SMA actuators, the improvements are more pronounced for the two-SMA actuator. The general theory (Scirè Mammano and Dragoni, 2011a) demonstrates that a single-SMA actuator can generate a truly constant output force for only one direction of motion. By contrast, a two-SMA actuator can achieve a constant output force in both directions.

Further advantages of the compensated architecture over regular SMA actuators are the existence of definite equilibrium positions when the power is turned off, the enforcement of precise mono (single SMA) or binary (two SMA) positioning, and the possibility of simple control strategies.

sec.title: Modeling of the shape memory material
sec.p: In order to design compensated shape memory actuators, a material model must be defined, which can describe the mechanical behavior of the alloy in two temperature ranges: below the temperature Mf at which the austenite–martensite transformation is finished (OFF or deactivated or disabled state) and above the temperature Af at which the martensite–austenite transformation is completed (ON or activated or enabled state). In these two conditions, inside the shape memory material, there is only one crystalline phase, and therefore, the macroscopic mechanical properties are those of that particular phase.

Normally, the mechanical behavior of a SMA element at high temperatures (austenite) is linear within the working range and is characterized by the elastic modulus Ea. At cold temperatures (martensite), the behavior can be satisfactorily interpolated with a bilinear law (Lagoudas, 2008) defined by a first leg with an elastic modulus Ema and a second leg with a gradient Emb. Let εg be the deformation of the point where of the change of slope takes place.

Due to the bilinear stress–strain response, the SMA elements used in the actuators (springs or wires) also have a bilinear force–displacement behavior when disabled (Figure 2). The elastic moduli Ea, Ema, and Emb are replaced by the stiffnesses Ka,Kma, and Kmb, while the deformation εg is replaced by the displacement xg. Since εg (then xg) is very small, the force–stroke characteristic of the SMA elements can be approximated as a linear trend, with slope Kmb, starting from the force F0m in correspondence to zero displacement (Figure 2). The force F0m is calculated as

caption.p: Force–deflection curves of the SMA springs used in the prototype.

sec.p: To facilitate the design of the actuator, it is useful to define the following dimensionless coefficients

Parameter s1 is the ratio of the stiffness at hot temperature and the stiffness of the elastic path at cold temperatures, while sm is the ratio between the two stiffnesses of the alloy at cold temperatures. Both parameters are characteristic of the shape memory material. Parameter sg is the ratio of the deflection, xg, at which the change in stiffness in the martensitic state is recorded and the maximum allowable deflection xadm, related to the maximum deformation, εadm, tolerated by the material. To limit the size of the device, it is convenient to assume the maximum deflection of the elements in the actuator xmax = xadm so as to exploit the material to the full.

The input data required for the design of a shape memory actuator are the value of the guaranteed minimum useful force in the two directions of activation (FON and FOFF in the case of a single-SMA element, and FON1 and FON2 when there are two opposing SMA elements); the value of the stroke desired, S; and the type of alloy that makes up the active elements (i.e. s1, sm, and sg). In the following equations, assuming that the axis of the actuator is horizontal, the forces are assumed positive when directed from right to left and negative when directed from left to right. The displacements are assumed positive from left to right.

sec.title: Theory of compensated single-SMA actuators
sec.p: Following Scirè Mammano and Dragoni (2011a), the design of compensated actuators with a single-SMA element is simplified by introducing the ratio, γ, between the stroke and the maximum deflection of the SMA element

The axial space taken up by the actuator is reduced as the ratio γ tends to unity because in that case all of the deformation that the material can sustain is used to produce a useful stroke. The value γ cannot however be unitary because the minimum deflection would be zero and the SMA element would not be able to exert useful forces.
The stiffness needed to fulfill the minimum force demand in both directions and to achieve the desired stroke is
From equations (2) and (6), the stiffness ka of the SMA element in the austenitic state is readily obtained.

The next step is to set the desired characteristics of the compensation element in terms of stiffness (kcomp) and force (

), delivered at position x = xmin (= xmax−S = S(1 −γ)/γ). Though the compensation stiffness can be set as desired in the range from −kmb to −ka, for kcomp = −ka, the force of the activated actuator is constant, and for kcomp = −kmb, the force of the deactivated actuator is constant. If we set kcomp = −0.5(ka+kmb), the deviation from uniformity of both states of actuator is minimized (Scirè Mammano and Dragoni, 2011a).
The force delivered from the actuator at position x = xmin to obtain the desired behavior must be

sec.title: Theory of compensated two-SMA actuators
sec.p: For a compensated actuator with two antagonistic SMA elements, it can be shown (Scirè Mammano and Dragoni, 2011a) that it is always possible to set the ratio γ (5) to 1, so that the actuator stroke is equal to the maximum deflection imposed on the SMA elements (xmin = 0). Figure 3 shows the force–displacement diagram of a two-SMA actuator and helps understand the general relationship between the variables involved in the following mathematical development.

caption.p: Force–deflection curves of a two-SMA actuator compensated by a generic elastic spring (line ED).

sec.p: Line OA in Figure 3 represents the characteristics of the austenitic (hot) SMA1 element. Segment BC represents the martensitic (cold) response of the antagonistic SMA2 element. Line DE is the characteristics of the compensation spring, with point D corresponding to the center point of the total stroke S of the actuator. Line EG represents an ideally constant external load of amplitude FON1. The situation beyond point D is obtained by extrapolating linearly all the characteristic lines shown in Figure 3. Line AE corresponds to the characteristics of the SMA1 element end the compensation spring combined. At any position x, the difference between lines AE and BC gives the net output force of the actuator (FnetON1) when element SMA1 is activated. When element SMA1 is disabled and SMA2 is enabled, the chart becomes similar to Figure 3, with all the lines mirrored with respect to the centerline AD.

The optimal performance of the actuator in Figure 3 is achieved when lines AE and BC become parallel to each other, so that the net output force of the actuator (FnetON1) equals the external load (FON1) at any position x. Scirè Mammano and Dragoni (2011a) demonstrated that the optimal actuator meets the design specifications (i.e. the given output forces FON1, FON2 and the net stroke S) when the following relationships hold true

sec.title: Prototype design
sec.p: The theory outlined in section “Theory” was applied to a two-SMA actuator based on the compensation rocker arm mechanism shown in Figure 4. The actuator is powered by commercial NiTi springs supplied by SAES Getters (Milan, Italy). For the sake of comparison, two otherwise identical actuators were built, one compensated and the other uncompensated, both equipped with identical SMA springs, installed with the same overall prestretch.

caption.p: Spring-assisted oscillating rocker arm used as elastic compensation mechanism.

sec.title: Experimental characterization of the SMA springs
sec.p: The SMA springs have the following characteristics: material = NiTi alloy (Af = 94°C and Mf = 57°C), wire diameter = 0.65 mm, mean coil diameter = 6.8 mm, number of active coils = 25.5, and free length l0 = 25 mm.

The springs were tested on an electromechanical testing machine SUN 500 (Galdabini, Varese, Italy) operated at a rate of 50 mm/min. Figure 2 shows the experimental force–deflection curves of the springs in the martensitic (solid circles) and austenitic (hollow circles) states. The martensitic curve was obtained by extending the spring by 100 mm starting from the undeformed, closely coiled shape. The austenitic curve was obtained by letting the spring recovering the undeformed length, starting from the deformed configuration. The austenitic transformation was achieved and maintained by supplying the spring with a steady current of 2600 mA at room temperature.

Superimposed on the experimental points, Figure 2 shows the bilinear interpolation law for the martensitic state (solid line) and the linear interpolation for the austenitic state (dashed line), which were used in the theoretical modeling of the springs. The theoretical parameters defining the interpolating lines in Figure 2 are ka = 0.0615 N/mm, kma = 0.0414 N/mm, kmb = 0.0156 N/mm, and xg = 22.8 mm. By assuming a maximum deflection, xadm = 100 mm (hence a net stroke S = 100 mm), the following dimensionless material parameters are calculated as follows: s1 = 1.486, sm = 0.377, and sg = 0.228.

sec.title: Functional design of the compensation system
sec.p: Using the above-mentioned dimensionless parameters, equation (8) gives the maximum force differential (FON1−FON2) that the actuator can produce in both directions as
Assuming that the actuator generates the same output force regardless of the direction of motion, yields

From equation (10), the overall stiffness of the compensation system is calculated as kcomp= −0.0771 N/mm. Likewise, equation (11) gives the force F0comp = 3.855 N that the compensator must apply to the SMA elements in the leftmost position x = 0.

sec.title: Kinematic design of the rocker arm compensator
sec.p: Of the two compensating mechanisms, a rocker arm and a double articulated quadrilateral, proposed in Scirè Mammano and Dragoni (2011a), the rocker arm concept shown in Figure 4 was chosen here for its simplicity.

The linkage in Figure 4 is made up of a rocker arm R hinged in G to the frame T. The elastic compensation spring SC (with free length L0Trad and spring rate kTrad) links the extremity F of the shortest side of the rocker arm to point E of the frame. Point O is used to connect the primary active springs of the actuator (SMA1 and SMA2) and represents the mechanical output port of the actuator. The other ends of the active springs are also fixed to the frame at points P and Q.

According to the theoretical development in Scirè Mammano and Dragoni (2011a), point O should be guided vertically and should be coupled with the rocker arm through a sliding pair. However, for small rotation angles (β = ±20°), the much simpler kinematic solution in Figure 4 (with a hinge instead of two sliders) works well.
For small rotations of the rocker arm, the vertical displacement S12 of the output port O traveling between the two angular positions β1 and β2 is given by

The rocker arm in Figure 4 has a position of unstable equilibrium corresponding to the configuration where the axis EF of the compensation spring Sc passes through the hinge G of the rocker arm. This condition happens when point O is at the center of the stroke S (x = S/2). In this way, the compensation mechanism favors the contraction of the active spring SMA1 through the lower half of the stroke and of the active spring SMA2 through the upper half of the stroke.

If β in Figure 4 is small, the theory in Scirè Mammano and Dragoni (2011a) shows that given the lengths b and c and the stiffness of the compensation spring, kTrad, the free length of the compensation spring, L0Trad, and the distance a, which define the correct sizing of the compensation mechanism, are given by
and
with
In equation (15), force F0Trad indicates the preload introduced in the compensation spring at manufacturing.

Using for F0comp, kcomp, and l, the values given in the previous section, from equation (16), the length a = 75 mm is obtained. To limit the maximum rotations of the rocker below 20° (= arcsin S/2c), the length c = 145 mm is chosen.

The elastic compensation spring Sc was a commercial extension spring with mean coil diameter of 10 mm, wire diameter of 2 mm, 34 closely wound coils, and free length L0Trad of 97 mm. The measured spring rate of the compensation spring, kTrad, was 2.05 N/mm and the preload, F0Trad, was 23.6 N. With these data, iterative solution of equations (15) and (17) finally gives the arm length b of 40.8 mm.

By removal of the compensation spring Sc, the system in Figure 4 becomes a classical (i.e. uncompensated) two-SMA actuator. One such actuator was actually built and used as a benchmark for the compensated actuator as described earlier.

sec.title: Theoretical performance of the actuator
sec.p: By modeling the SMA as illustrated in Figure 2 (linear austenitic behavior and bilinear martensitic response), the net force generated by the compensated actuator for the three characteristic operational states is given by the following relationships (Scirè Mammano and Dragoni, 2011a)

where the Boolean operator
〈 Expression 〉
assumes the values 1 or 0 according to whether Expression is TRUE or FALSE. The meaning of most symbols in equations (18) to (20) is clarified in Figure 3.
For the uncompensated actuator (F0comp = kcomp = 0 in the former equations), the net forces become

For the design parameters defined in the previous section, the theoretical forces (18) to (23) are shown with solid lines in Figure 5(a) for the uncompensated actuator and in Figure 5(b) for the compensated actuator. In both charts, the position x of the output port ranges from zero to the nominal design stroke (S = 100 mm) of the compensated device.

caption.p: Output forces generated by the (a) uncompensated and (b) compensated actuators for three operating conditions.

sec.title: Prototype construction
sec.p: Figure 6 shows the prototype assembly with the compensated actuator in the foreground and the uncompensated actuator in the background. The compensated actuator is equipped with hard stops, which limit the overall stroke to 96 mm, placed symmetrically with respect to the center position of the port O. Both rocker arms are made of aluminum alloy and are supported by ball bearings at hinges G to minimize friction. Likewise, the compensation spring is connected in E to the frame and in F to the rocker arm through ball bearings.

caption.p: Front view of the experimental rig featuring the compensated (bottom) and uncompensated (top) actuators.

sec.p: For each actuator, the external working force was provided by a magnetic hysteresis rotary brake HB3M-2 (mobac GmbH, Kiel, Germany) with rated torque of 20 N mm. The brakes and the electronics of the system were placed at the bottom of the main plate as shown in Figure 7. The brakes were connected to the output ports O of the two actuators by means of nylon cables, guided by antifriction pulleys and wound on a drum fitted to the input shaft of each brake according to the arrangement sketched in Figure 8. When the output port O in Figure 8 translates (e.g. to right), the nylon cables produce a clockwise rotation of the drum, to which the brake reacts with an anticlockwise braking torque. The braking torque generates a force unbalance in the cable, which is returned to the output port as a constant resisting force.

caption.p: Back view of the experimental rig showing circuitry and transducers.
PCB: printed circuit board; SMA: shape memory alloy.
Schematic representation of the braking system used to apply dissipative external forces to the output port of the actuators.

sec.p: Hysteresis brakes produce torque through a magnetic air gap without the use of magnetic particles or friction components. This method of braking provides very smooth torque at any speed, superior repeatability, high degree of controllability, and negligible drag and strict proportionality between brake torque and supply current. The use of these electrical brakes allowed the force acting on the actuators to be finely tuned between 0.05 and 3.2 N by adjusting the supply current through the potentiometers shown in Figure 6. The current–torque characteristic curve provided by the brake manufacturer helped establish the correspondence between supply current and applied force. The brakes were powered by an electronic board (Figure 7), which implemented a control loop with current feedback. The board uses two linear voltage regulators LT3080 (Linear Technology Corporation, Milpitas, CA, USA) operated in current–source mode either by the potentiometers in Figure 6 or through a signal generated by the computer.

The angular position of the rocker arms was measured during operation by contactless rotary position sensors NRH280DP (Penny+Giles Controls Ltd, Christchurch, UK). The sensors were mounted on the back face of the main plate (Figure 7) to fit the rotation axes G of both actuators.

Heating of the SMA springs was achieved by Joule effect upon circulation of electrical current supplied by two independent electronic boards (Figure 7). Each board implements a current control loop to provide a steady supply current in response to a voltage signal.

sec.title: Test variables and procedures
sec.p: Testing of the actuators was performed by measuring the following variables: the supply voltages and currents of the SMA springs, the supply currents of the brakes, and the angular positions of the rocker arms. All these variables were managed by a National Instruments board USB6251 running a custom LabVIEW program. The program allowed the acquisition, the display, and the storage of the experimental data according to the needs of the characterization and identification of the prototype actuators.

Two testing procedures were carried out to characterize the actuators, each starting by first setting the external braking force to a specified value and then measuring the corresponding stroke and actuation time. The force levels investigated ranged from 0 to 1.7 N, in steps of 0.1 N for both procedures.

In the first procedure, the actuators started from a position in which one of the two-SMA springs was activated and the other disabled. The activation states of the springs were then suddenly reversed until a new equilibrium configuration was achieved. Finally, the activation states were reversed again to restore the starting configuration. This procedure showed the maximum stroke produced by the actuators and the characteristic activation times needed to complete a single stroke and a full cycle.

In the second procedure, the actuators started from the equilibrium position in which both SMA springs were disabled (i.e. port O situated at the center point of the stroke, for the uncompensated actuator, or placed at either end of the stroke, for the compensated actuator). One of the two-SMA springs was then activated until a new equilibrium configuration was achieved. This procedure showed again the maximum stroke produced by the actuators and the characteristic activation times needed to complete a single stroke from the fully disabled state.

In both procedures, the activated SMA springs were supplied by a steady current of 2600 mA. This value was identified in exploratory tests as the maximum current capable of triggering and maintaining the full austenite transformation without damaging the alloy by overheating.

sec.title: Test results
sec.p: Table 1 summarizes the experimental results obtained in the first test procedure (two complete strokes starting from the equilibrium configurations of the activated actuators). For all the values of the output force examined (applied by the magnetic brakes), Table 1 reports for each actuator (uncompensated and compensated) the measured stroke, the predicted stroke, and the cycle time. The linear stroke was calculated from the angular readings of the rotary sensors using equation (14). The cycle time was measured automatically by the acquisition system at the achievement of the equilibrium positions in the activation states explored by the procedure. Detection of the equilibrium positions was easy for the compensated actuator equipped with hard stops but more difficult for the uncompensated actuator where the final position is determined by the forces applied by the SMA springs. In this case, the equilibrium position was defined as the position in which the motion of the rocker arm happened at a rate lower than 0.01° per second.

caption.p: Test results starting from the activated actuators.

sec.p: For a better comparison with the theoretical predictions, the force–displacement points acquired during testing (and leading to the data shown in Table 1) are superimposed in Figure 5 to the theoretical curves for both actuators. A direct comparison of the net strokes and cycle times from Table 1 is presented in Figure 9(a) and (b) for the compensated (solid circles) and uncompensated (hollow circles) actuators.

caption.p: Comparison between compensated and uncompensated actuator performance in terms of (a) net stroke, (b) cycle time, (c) stroke time, and (d) response time.

sec.p: Table 2 summarizes the experimental results obtained in the second test procedure (a single stroke starting from the equilibrium configurations of the deactivated actuators). For each output force, three measurements are presented for each actuator: the stroke produced by activating one spring (net stroke), the time needed to complete the stroke (stroke time), and the response time, defined as the time consumed to cover a displacement of 1 mm.

caption.p: Test results starting from the deactivated actuators.

sec.p: The equilibrium position of the output port in the deactivated uncompensated actuator is not well defined due to the friction forces in the joints and the cooling sequence of the SMA springs. For this reason, the test procedure was performed on the uncompensated actuator twice, once by activating the left SMA spring and then by activating the right SMA spring. The net stroke was defined as the distance between the port positions reached at the end of each activation step. The stroke time is the average of the times needed to complete each step. Likewise, also the response time is the average from the measurements made during activations in the two opposite directions.
The stroke times and response times from Table 2 are compared graphically in Figure 9(c) and (d) for the compensated (solid circles) and uncompensated (hollow circles) actuators.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Table 1 shows that the performance of both compensated and uncompensated actuators is somewhat lower than the theoretical predictions. For the uncompensated actuator, the measured stroke is lower than expectations by about 10%–15% when the output force is low and about 30%–40% for the higher applied forces. For the compensated actuator, the maximum stroke is always the same (96 mm, limited by the hard stops) but the experimental output force that the device can deliver (1.5 N) is 12% lower than the maximum theoretical force (1.7 N). For both actuators, the lower performance is attributable to the following three main reasons: First, the friction resistance, which affects the prototype response but was not included in the theoretical model; second, the bilinear model adopted for the martensite (Figure 2), which disregards small nonlinearities in the true material behavior; and finally, a progressive functional degradation of the alloy due to thermal cycling test after test. Apart from these minor deviations, the good correlation between theory and experiment is confirmed also by the force–displacement curves in Figure 5.

From Table 1 and Figure 9, it is seen that the compensated actuators outperforms its uncompensated counterpart in many ways. To begin with, for any given output force, the net stroke is larger, the ratio between the strokes being 2.5 times at zero load and 22 times under the maximum force of 1.5 N (Figure 9(a)). Furthermore, the net stroke of the compensated actuator is independent of the applied force, which simplifies both the design and the selection of the actuator for a given application. Another remarkable advantage of the compensated actuator lies in the nearly constant value of the output force. This feature, which is visible in Figure 5(b) (nearly horizontal lines in the activated states), was checked by attaching to the output port a dead weight of 1.5 N. The actuator assumed any intermediate position between the hard stops, hold in equilibrium by the constant weight.

The final advantage of the compensated actuator that emerges from Table 1 and Figure 9(b) involves the cycle time (i.e. the time taken to accomplish two subsequent strokes, starting from a state in which one SMA spring is activated). The cycle time is comparable for the two actuators when the force is high, but is nearly double for the uncompensated actuator under negligible forces. This is likely due to two reasons: First, the cycle time is mainly determined by the cooling time of the springs, which is similar for both actuators, and second, due to the lesser difference between internal force and external force close in the end equilibrium positions, the uncompensated actuator has a longer time constant before coming to rest.

The values of the net strokes reported in Table 2 for the uncompensated actuator are appreciably lower than those listed in Table 1. This is presumably imputable to degradation of the SMA because of overheating from the constant current supply scheme. A slight loss of performance in Table 2 can be observed also for the compensated actuator since the full stroke is achieved only up to a load of 1.4 N against the maximum force of 1.5 N in Table 1. The greater robustness with respect to thermal degradation of the springs is another distinguished advantage of the compensation concept.

The time to complete a single stroke (Table 2 and Figure 9(c)) is again quicker for the compensated actuator than for the uncompensated one. The reasons for this difference are essentially the same as those explaining the difference in the cycle times in Table 1. By contrast, the response time (the time needed to achieve a displacement of 1 mm) is considerably shorter for the uncompensated actuator (Table 2 and Figure 9(d)). This behavior is due to the lower stress at which the SMA springs operate before activation, which requires a lesser degree of martensite–austenite transformation (hence a lesser temperature) to begin the motion.

The advantages in terms of strokes at given output force shown in Table 1 and Figure 9(a) come as a consequence of a common prestretch (100 mm) of the two-SMA springs in both actuators. If the compensated actuator was to be designed to produce the same force and the same stroke as the uncompensated actuator, the prestretch in its SMA springs could be much lower than in the uncompensated actuator. As a consequence, the strain and the stress in the SMA would be lower with positive consequences on the fatigue life of the device. For example, under a force of 1.5 N, the compensated actuator would provide the same theoretical stroke as the uncompensated actuator (5.3 mm, Table 1) for a prestretch of only 5.3 mm against the 100 mm needed by the uncompensated actuator. This is an alternative way to see the advantages of the compensation concept.

The main limitation of the present design is the considerable occupied volume, which would be a major concern in many practical applications. However, this study is to be regarded only as a first step of the research aimed to demonstrate the feasibility of the compensation technology. Based on the same general theory of the present design, more compact architectures can be developed so as to retain the proved advantages with minimum space penalty. Apart from the occupied space, no other environmental issues affect the compensated SMA actuation more than the standard design.

Our ongoing research on the subject of elastic compensation involves three topics: First, implement the compensation force by means of compliant mechanisms, in order to achieve a greater degree of mechanical integration and reduce the overall dimensions; second, compare the performance decay and the functional fatigue behavior of compensated and uncompensated actuators under cyclic loading. Experience on functional fatigue has already been accumulated by the authors with tests on SMA wires under constant stress and constant strain loading conditions (Scirè Mammano and Dragoni, 2011b, in press); and the third line of research involves the definition of the optimal supply current for the compensated actuator to reduce the effect of thermal degradation of the active SMA elements.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The concept of elastic compensation of SMA actuators has been investigated experimentally on a two-SMA prototype actuator featuring a spring-assisted rocker arm mechanism as compensation system. The compensator accumulates energy from the SMA elements in the positions where the SMA force is higher than the external force and returns that energy to the actuator in the positions where the SMA force is low. Designed according to a general theory developed by the authors in a previous publication, the compensated actuator confirms quantitatively the advantages predicted theoretically with respect to uncompensated actuators of equal architecture. Under constant external forces, the compensated actuator produces net strokes from 2.5 to 22 times greater than the uncompensated counterpart (the higher the force, the higher the stroke improvement). Weaknesses of the compensated design are the heavier average stress sustained by the SMA springs, which could impair the fatigue life, and a higher response time at the very beginning of the motion after activation.

sec.title: Nomenclature
sec.p: a, b, c Lengths defining the rocker arm mechanism
ka Elastic spring rate of the austenitic SMA element
kcomp Spring rate of the elastic compensation system
kma Elastic spring rates of the martensitic SMA element
kmb Pseudoplastic spring rates of a shape memory element in the martensitic state
kTrad Spring rate of the elastic compensation spring in the rocker arm mechanism
l0 Free length of the SMA elements in single-SMA and double-SMA actuators
sg Ratio between the strain at onset of the pseudoplastic plateaux and the admissible strain of the SMA
sm Martensite parameter of the SMA
s1 Efficiency parameter of the SMA
x Position of the mechanical output port of the actuator
xadm Maximum allowable deflection of the SMA element
xg Deflection of the martensitic SMA element at onset of the pseudoplastic plateaux
xmax Maximum working deflections of the SMA element within the actuator
xmin Minimum working deflection of the SMA element within the actuator
Af Austenite finish temperature
B Design parameter for the rocker arm compensator
Ea Austenite Young’s modulus
Ema Martensite Young’s modulus
Emb Martensite pseudoplastic slope
FnetON1 Net force generated by the double-SMA actuator when only element 1 is activated
FnetON2 Net force generated by the double-SMA actuator when only element 2 is activated
FnetOFF Net force generated by the actuator when all SMA elements are deactivated
FOFF Design force for the single-SMA actuator in the deactivated state
FON Design force for the single-SMA actuator in the activated state
FON1 Design force for the double-SMA actuator when only element 1 is activated
FON2 Design force for the double-SMA actuator when only element 2 is activated
F0comp Force generated by the elastic compensator at x = 0
F0m Virtual force produced by the SMA element at zero deflection in the linearized model
F0Trad Preload of the compensation spring
L0Trad Free length of the compensation spring in the rocker arm mechanism
Mf Martensite finish temperature
S Design stroke of the actuator
S12 Displacement of the actuator between angular positions β1 and β2 of the rocker arm
β Angular position of the rocker arm
εadm Maximum allowable strain of the SMA
εg Strain of the martensitic SMA at onset of the pseudoplastic plateaux
γ Design parameter of the actuator

ack.p: The supply by SAES Getters of the SMA springs used in the prototypes is gratefully acknowledged by the authors. This article was presented at the ASME 2011 Conference on Smart Materials, Adaptive Structures and Intelligent Systems—SMASIS 2011, 18–21 September 2011, Scottsdale, Arizona, USA. Paper number SMASIS2011-4924.

fn.p: This research was partially funded by the Office for Industrial Development of Italy’s Regione Emilia Romagna.
